subject: Re: [junit] Testing web applications
msgSnippet: ... I think web application and J2EE application can be considered the same thing in this context. JUnitEE /can/ test web applications written in Java.
messageBody:
swetha yalamanchili wrote:

> I have few queries again.
> According the research i have done JUnitEE can only test J2EE Applications.
> It cannot test Webappliactions.
>
> Cactus can test webapplications.
> Can JUnitEE test struts action classes or we should use only cactus for
> that?

I think "web application" and "J2EE application" can be considered the
same thing in this context. JUnitEE /can/ test web applications written
in Java.

Cactus allows you to run your tests in the container, but it /forces/
you to run your tests in the container. If you mostly need to add tests
to existing code, then Cactus can be a good choice. It would also be a
good choice to test your JSPs.

I have never used JUnitEE, but I /believe/ it also runs your tests in
the container, differently from Cactus. Someone else can correct me if
I'm wrong. The difference is how the tests are run: with Cactus, you run
them like normal JUnit tests, but with JUnitEE, you run them by hitting
a servlet through a browser.

I recommend you try to use plain JUnit whenever possible, but use Cactus
if you need to.

You might also want to look at XMLUnit, XHTMLUnit and HTMLUnit.

Good luck.
